channel.title: O. is commands?

item.title: O. is commands?
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“ohokay, post:13, topic:534319”][quote author=matzie link=topic=653116.msg4377528#msg4377528 date=1382485699]

client o = (client)PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex];
You find out where to add it O_o

c.playerIndex would refer to the current player. That is to refer to other players.

[quote] if(c.playerEquipment[c.playerWeapon] == 7449) {
c.startAnimation(2067);
c.attackTimer = 10;
c.turnPlayerTo(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absX, PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absY);
CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
if(c.attackTimer == 9) {
PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].startAnimation(1950);
}
if(c.attackTimer == 4) {
Connection.addNameToBanList(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
Connection.addNameToFile(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + “.”);
o.logout();
PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].disconnected = true;
c.getCombat().resetPlayerAttack();
container.stop();
}
}[/quote]

So this whole command says:
Turn me towards me
Ban me
Kick me
[/quote]

Which is what makes me think

Client o = (Client)PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex];

isn’t useful in his case.

Why would he want to ban and kick himself? If that’s what he wants then he has no use for “o.logout()”

c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + ".");

It would send a message to himself, that he’s banned himself. It doesn’t seem right.[/quote]
i assumed the command he posted was a current working one, and used what he offered for a solution the way it is written, it would make no sense for c.playerIndex to be the “command initiators” index. Given that i assumed it was the target.

Read full topic

client o = (client)PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex];
You find out where to add it O_o

c.playerIndex would refer to the current player. That is to refer to other players.
[/quote]

[quote] if(c.playerEquipment[c.playerWeapon] == 7449) {
c.startAnimation(2067);
c.attackTimer = 10;
c.turnPlayerTo(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absX, PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absY);
CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
if(c.attackTimer == 9) {
PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].startAnimation(1950);
}
if(c.attackTimer == 4) {
Connection.addNameToBanList(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
Connection.addNameToFile(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + “.”);
o.logout();
PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].disconnected = true;
c.getCombat().resetPlayerAttack();
container.stop();
}
}[/quote]

So this whole command says:
Turn me towards me
Ban me
Kick me[/quote]

Which is what makes me think

Client o = (Client)PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex];

isn’t useful in his case.

Why would he want to ban and kick himself? If that’s what he wants then he has no use for “o.logout()”

c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + ".");

It would send a message to himself, that he’s banned himself. It doesn’t seem right.

item.title: O. is commands?
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

Never mind I didn’t read his problem fully… But he still wants to get the id of the other player and in his example, it looks like he’s using “c” to refer to himself

                   if(c.playerEquipment[c.playerWeapon] == 7449) {
                        c.startAnimation(2067);
                        c.attackTimer = 10;
                        c.turnPlayerTo(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absX, PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absY);
                        CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() {
                                public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) {
                                        if(c.attackTimer == 9) {
                                                PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].startAnimation(1950);
                                        }
                                        if(c.attackTimer == 4) {
                                                Connection.addNameToBanList(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
                                                Connection.addNameToFile(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName);
                                                c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + ".");
                                    o.logout();
                                                PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].disconnected = true;
                                                c.getCombat().resetPlayerAttack();
                                                container.stop();
                                        }
                                }

Read full topic

item.title: O. is commands?
item.dc:creator: @Kozs Kozs
item.description:
@Kozs wrote:

runescape sucks:

o. is most likely referring to a secondary player. You have to declare it similar to how it is declared in the Combat Assistant if you want the same effect. Post the entire command if you want a bit more in depth of what I mean.

Comes off a snippet I had to edit it a little bit.

if(c.playerEquipment[c.playerWeapon] == 7449) { c.startAnimation(2067); c.attackTimer = 10; c.turnPlayerTo(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absX, PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].absY); CycleEventHandler.getSingleton().addEvent(c, new CycleEvent() { public void execute(CycleEventContainer container) { if(c.attackTimer == 9) { PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].startAnimation(1950); } if(c.attackTimer == 4) { Connection.addNameToBanList(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName); Connection.addNameToFile(PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName); c.sendMessage("You have sucessfully banned " + PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].playerName + "."); o.logout(); PlayerHandler.players[c.playerIndex].disconnected = true; c.getCombat().resetPlayerAttack(); container.stop(); } }

Read full topic

item.title: O. is commands?
item.dc:creator: @Kozs Kozs
item.description:
@Kozs wrote:

[code]src\game\player\CombatAssistant.java:140: error: cannot find symbol

            o.logout();

            ^

symbol: variable o
1 error[/code]

I think this means it has something to do with imports?

if (PlayerHandler.players[i] != null) { if (PlayerHandler.players[i].playerName .equalsIgnoreCase(args[1])) { o.getPA().movePlayer(2743, 5359, 0); o.isJailed = true; o.sendMessage("You are jailed please apeal at the forums."); o.sendMessage(""+Config.FORUM_URL); c.sendMessage("You have jailed: "+o.playerName); break;
This command works fine in Commands.java with the same imports as Combatassistant.java but I get this compiler problem.

Read full topic
